text.body:
Chapter 2 3
When
I had attained the age of
seventeen
my
father
parents
resolved that
I should
go to
become a student
at the university of In
golstadt.
I had hitherto attended the
schools of
Geneva,
but my father thought
it
necessary
for the completion of my
education that
that I should be
made acquainted with other customs
besides than
those of my native country. My depar
ture was therefore fixed
for at an
early
^
date. But
before the day resolved
upon could
arrive
the first mis
fortune of my life
occurred: as if an
omen
as it
were
of my future
miseryif
I should prosecute my journey.
>Elizabeth
had caught the scar
let
fever but
her illness was
not severe and she quickly recovered.
During her
confinement
mady
^
made
many
ar
guments had been urged to persuade
my mother
not a
to refrain from
to attend
upon
her. She
had yielded
the to these
to our
entreaties,
but
when she
ha heard that
her
favourite was
recovering,
she
w c ould
no longer
debar herself from her
society, and entered her sick cham
ber long before it was safe the danger of infection was past .
The
consequences of this imprudence were
fatal:
on the third day my mother
sickened.
Her fever was
very
malig
nant,
tr and the looks of her
atten
dants prognosticated the
wort worst
evil.
On her
death bed
the forti
tude and benignity
di of
my mother
this
admirable woman
did not desert her. She joined the
hands of Elizabeth and
myself. "My
"children said she it was on your
"union that my firmest hopes of
"future happiness were placed. It
"will now be the consolation of
"your fathor father. alone
Elizabeth, my
"love,
supply my place to
the other
"your young cons cousins.
Alas! I
" almost regret
being
than
I am taken from
you,
" h and
happy and
beloved,
as I
am
"is
it not hard to quit you all? But
"these
are not thoughts befitting
me
"I
^
will endeavour to resign myself
to cheerfully to
"death
and will indulge a hope
my
" beloved creatures of meeting you
"in
another world."
She died
calmly
and her
features
expressed
lov affection even in death.
I need not describe the feelings of those
whose dearest ties are rent by that
most
irreperable
evil;
the
bla void
that
every where presents itself to
their
^
minds
the
soul
and the despair that
is exhibited on the countenance.
It is so long before the mind can
persuade itself that she, whom
they
saw every day, and whose very
existence appeared a part of
theirs,
can have departed for
ever: T t hat
the brightness of a
loved
eye can have
faded
been extinguished,
and the sound of a voice
never
so
familiar
and dear to the
ear
can be hushed, never more to be
heard. These are the reflections of the
first
days.
But when the lapse of
time proves the reality of the
evil
then the
true despair
bitterness of grief
commences ,
Then the survivors dare not turn
But
Yet,
from whom
who has not
had some dear
connection rent away by that rude hand
rent away some
dear
connection,
and why
need
should
I describe a sorrow
which all have felt, and must
feel?
But
t T he
time at length
arrives
when grief is rather an indulgence
a than a
necessity
and the smile
that plays
on
the lips, although
it
is
deemed
sacriledge, is not Ba
nished.–
My mother
was gone lost had be en
taken
^
away
was
dead
but we had still
duties which we ought to
perform
we must continue our course with
the
rest & bless God if nothing
else
^
worse
hap
pens
.
and the idleness generated by grief would
become a bad habit if further indulged
and learn
to think
our
selves fortu
nate, if no
more
whilst
one remains
whom the
spoiler has
not seized.
My
journey to
Ingolstadt
which had
been deferred by these
events
was now
again determined
upon, and all that
I
could obtained from my father was a
respite of some weeks. This time
was spent
sadly.
My
mothers death
and my speedy
departure
depressed
our
spirits
but Elizabeth endeavour
ed to
spr renew the spirit
cast aa gleam
renew the spirit
of
cheer
fullness
in our little society. Since
the death of her
aunt
her mind
had acquired new
firmess firmness and
vigour. She determined to fulfil her
duties with the greatest
exactitude
and
her
she felt that
the
most imperious
duty was
of
to rendering
her uncle and cousins
hap
py.
had devolved
on
her.
She consoled me, amused her uncle,
and instructed my
brothers
and I
never
beheld her so enchanting as at this
time when she sar sacrifised every
minut e of her time to others
^
was
continual
ly endeavouring to contribute to the
happiness of others entirely forgetful
The day of my departure at
lenghth
arrived – I had taken leave of all
my friends excepting Clerval, who spent
the last evening with us.
He bitterly la
mented that he was
not able
unable
to
accompany
me
But his father
could not
bear
be persuaded
to part with
him
besides as he intend ed ing
him to
that he should
be
come a partner with him in
his business,
and he said he did not
and in
compliance
with his favou
rite theory,
that
the learning
was
superflous
in the com
merce of ordi
nary life.
see
^
of
what use learning
was
^
could be
to a
merchant. Henry
had a refined mind
and a he did not wish had no desire to be idle
and was well pleased to become the
partner of his father's
^
partner but he believed
that a man might be a very good
trader and yet have posess a cultivated
mind. understanding.
We
sate late
listening to his com
plaints, and
I making many little
arrangements for the future.
and
t T he
next morning early I departed. Tears
gushed from the eyes of
Elizabeth
they proceeded partly from sorrow
at my departure, and partly because
she reflected that the same journey
was to have taken place three
months
before
when a
mothers
blessing would have accompanied
me
I threw myself into the chaise
that was to convey me
away
and in
dulged in the most melancholy reflec
tions.
I
who had ever been surrounded
by amiable companions, continually
engaged in
ed endeavouring to
give
mutual
pleasure;
I was now alone.
In the university wi
whither I was
going
I must form my own
friends
and be my own
introduction .
protector.
My
life had hitherto been remarkably
retired
and
domestic
and this had given me
an invincible repugnance to new
faces
countenances. I loved my
brothers Eliza
beth
and
Clerval
these were "old
familiar
faces"
but I believed my
self totally unfitted for the compa
ny of strangers. Such were my reflec
tions as I commenced my
journey
But
as I
proceeded
my spirits and hopes
rose. I ardently desired
knowledge
and I
I had
often
when at
home
thought
how
it
hard
it was to remain
during my youth
cooped up in one
place all my
life
and had longed to enter
into the
worth world
and take my
place
with
station
among
other human beings.
And
now my desires were
cop complyed
with
& it
would
^
indeed
have
be indeed
been folly to
repent.
I had
plenty of
sufficient
leisure for these
and many other reflections during
my journey to
Ingolstadt
which was
long and
fatiguing –
at length the
steeples
of the town met my eyes. I
alighted
and was conducted to my
solitary
apartment
to spend the
evening as I pleased.
